title: Baba, Mendelsohn, Ignash named Distinguished Alumni
text:
GRAND BLANC — Dr. Marietta Baba, Henry Mendelsohn, and Mark Ignash are the recipients of the 2025 Charlie A. Carmody Distinguished Alumni Awards.
Honorees are invited to return to their hometown to ride in the Homecoming parade. They are introduced during halftime at the game and are lauded at the alumni dinner where they receive plaques to commemorate the award.
Homecoming will take place Friday, Sept. 19. The Alumni Dinner will be held at 6 p.m. Saturday, Sept. 20, at Warwick Hills Golf & Country Club.
Pictures and biographies of all Distinguished Alumni are displayed in the Alumni Hallway at Grand Blanc High School’s East Campus.
Baba, a 1967 graduate, is an anthropologist who served as dean of the College of Social Science at Michigan State University from 2001-2015. She also worked as a professor and chair of the Department of Anthropology at Wayne State University.
Baba’s research has focused on the anthropology of work, organizations, and institutions; technological innovation in organizations, policy, and the history and theory of applied anthropology.
A scholar, leader, and educator for five decades, she has authored or co-authored more than 100 publications. Currently, she is executive director and president of the Foundation for Women and Children Enslaved in War, an organization providing support services to survivors of human trafficking in conflict zones who now reside in the United States.
A 1969 graduate, Mendelsohn is a librarian, educator, and Foreign Service officer. For 16 years, he worked as an academic librarian, predominantly at the University of Albany. Mendelsohn developed collections that supported research in social welfare and criminal justice and taught students how to access those resources.
In 1994, he joined the Foreign Service and spent twenty years in South Asia, the Middle East, and Africa. Among his activities abroad, Mendelsohn managed libraries at U.S. Embassies, served as a regional consultant to embassies, and taught foreign students, journalists, and academics how to find accurate and authoritative information.
The recipient of numerous State Department awards, as well as a Fellowship by the American Library Association, Mendelsohn currently works part-time reviewing documents for release under the Freedom of Information Act.
Ignash, who graduated in 2004, has fostered a career in public service focused on industry, community, talent development, and investment within the state of Michigan.
He currently serves as interim executive director of the Michigan Defense Center and Senior Sector Development director & Defense advisor at the Michigan Economic Development Corporation.
Ignash is responsible for the State of Michigan’s economic development portfolio related to the aerospace and defense industries, which have a multibillion dollar impact.
His work has centered on initiatives that attract business, drive industry innovation, and advocate for Michigan on the local, national, and international stages.
Since 2003, the GBHS Alumni Association has honored dozens of alumni with the Charlie A. Carmody Distinguished Alumni Award.
